title: A look at Atlanta's Colony Square
title_page: Photos: A look at Atlanta's Colony Square
text:
1 / 10
JASON GETZ / AJC FILE Midtown Atlanta’s Colony Square was decades ahead of its time. Now, the venerable mix of office towers and a shopping mall is about to play catch-up with the modern era.This week, noted developer North American Properties and equity partner Lionstone Investments closed on their purchase of the towers at 14th and Peachtree streets. -- All text in this gallery by J. Scott Trubey, AJC | READ THE STORY
2 / 10
Jamison Research, Incorported The duo has some intriguing ideas about how to remake Jim Cushman’s forward-thinking office complex — including taking the top off of the mall at the base of the skyscrapers — but they also want to know what the community thinks should be part of Colony Square’s revitalization. Cushman developed Colony Square, a mix of shops, restaurants, a hotel, residential and office towers in a project that was decades ahead of its time by Atlanta’s standards. Today, mixed-use is on everyone’s development radar, but in the 1960s, it was a rarity. | READ THE STORY
3 / 10
GEORGE CLARK / AJC FILE In this 1972 photo from the AJC archives, the original caption reads "Business is slow to return to 'strip' area of Midtown Atlanta around 10th Street. Cushman Corporation's Colony Square development rises in the background." | READ THE STORY
4 / 10
AJC FILE June 1977: Peachtree Street in midtown Atlanta, looking north. Colony Square comprises the two high rises in the distance. | READ THE STORY
5 / 10
AJC FILE June 1973: The Colony Square ice skating rink as it looked while under construction. The original photo caption reads "Colony Square rink nears completion. More Atlanta ice rink capacity will be available to local skaters on July 5 when the Colony Square Ice Capades Chalet opens its 8,800-square-foot floor. The rink is covered by a giant skylight. Shops surrounding the rink are to open this fall." | READ THE STORY
6 / 10
RAY WEST / AJC FILE By 1982, Colony Square had high rise company as the Midtown area continued growing and expanding. | READ THE STORY
7 / 10
Dillon-Reynolds Aerial Photo “Over the decades, the Midtown neighborhood around Colony Square flourished while the iconic building became sleepy and tired,” North American Managing Partner Mark Toro said in a news release. “On July 4, 2018, the 50th anniversary of Colony Square’s groundbreaking, we will celebrate the grand opening of the reimagined Colony Square. We will engage with the city, with the street and with pedestrians, and it will fundamentally change the experience of living and working in Midtown Atlanta.” -- Text by J. Scott Trubey, AJC | READ THE STORY
